titleStmt.title: Individual differences in speed-accuracy trade-off drive human group dynamics

affiliation.orgName: Max Planck Institute for Human Development
Max Planck Institute for Human Development
Max Planck Institute for Human Development
Leibniz-Institute of Freshwater Ecology and Inland Fisheries

analytic.title: Individual differences in speed-accuracy trade-off drive human group dynamics

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Speed-accuracy trade-offs are a fundamental aspect of decision-making, requiring individuals to balance collecting more information against making faster decisions. Although speed-accuracy trade-offs have been studied extensively at the individual level, their role in human group decision-making remains poorly understood-even though faster, and possibly more error-prone, decisions often influence group outcomes more than slower decisions. We examined how individual differences in speed-accuracy trade-off preferences shape decisionmaking in pairs, using an interactive online experiment and drift-diffusion modeling. Participants first performed a visual perception task alone, allowing us to estimate their individual drift rates and decision thresholds, the key cognitive determinants of speedaccuracy trade-off preferences. Participants then performed the task in pairs, sharing decisions in real time. Group accuracy depended on the faster (and thus more error-prone) member, and not on the slower (but more accurate) member. Social decisions were not worse than individual ones because faster members increased their thresholds in the social condition and became more accurate, while slower members incorporated less social information. These findings show that individuals adjusted their social information use to the speedaccuracy trade-off preferences of their group members, highlighting the importance of such individual differences for understanding collective behavior.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: A fundamental challenge for individuals during decision-making is the trade-off between speed and accuracy. When making decisions, individuals need to continuously choose between collecting more information, which generally leads to better decisions, and forgoing more information in order to make faster, but possibly more error-prone, decisions [1][2][3]. An individual foraging under predation risk [4][5][6] who invests little time in detecting predators may reap higher foraging rewards, but at the expense of a higher predation risk. Alternatively, they may invest more time in detecting predators, leading to more accurate predation detection, but at the expense of lower foraging returns. Evidence for such speed-accuracy trade-offs has been found across a wide range of animal species, including bees [7][8][9], ants [10,11], fish [12,13], and monkeys [14][15][16], and in humans (see [17,18] for reviews) across decision contexts such as perceptual [19], multisensory [20], and sample-based decisions [21].

Previous research on the role of speed-accuracy trade-offs in human decision-making has been largely limited to the individual level (but see [5] for a review on nonhuman gregarious animals and speed-accuracy trade-offs). Yet there is ample evidence that individuals consistently differ in how they navigate speed-accuracy trade-offs [19][20][21][22][23][24][25]. This means that in group decisions, individuals may be confronted with others with different speed-accuracy trade-off preferences and need to resolve possible conflicts. Furthermore, a range of studies have shown that decisions made earlier by members of a group (i.e., social information) have a strong influence on the other group members [26][27][28][29][30][31]. Such social information can even cause information cascades, where later-deciding individuals ignore their private information and follow the decisions of early-deciding individuals [32][33][34]. When the speed-accuracy trade-off preferences of individuals in groups differ, individuals who prefer speed over accuracy may therefore be the first individuals to make decisions (see also [35]). This, in turn, may lead to poorer decisions in groups. This prediction is somewhat at odds with most research on human group decision-making, which typically predicts benefits of social information exchange (e.g., [36,37]). However, few studies incorporate the natural timing of decisions; instead, they use round-based paradigms in which all individuals decide independently before exchanging information [29,38].

When individuals experience others' decisions in real-time, additional information is available that may change the collective dynamics. For example, group members may weight social information as a function of how quickly it arrives [39][40][41][42] and/or its accuracy [43][44][45]. Moreover, individuals could adjust the timing of their decisions in light of other group members' tendencies. These and other mechanisms could therefore mitigate a drop in accuracy in groups in which members with different speed-accuracy trade-off preferences share decisions in real time.

To understand the cognitive dispositions that make group members leaders or followers in decisions featuring speed-accuracy trade-offs, the way group members use social information from leaders, and the collective dynamics and outcomes that emerge, we conducted a binary perceptual decision-making task with real-time information exchange (Figure 1a). First, participants conducted the task alone, allowing us to quantify individual differences in speedaccuracy trade-off preference. They then conducted the same task while paired randomly with another participant, with real-time exchange of decisions. Participants' behavior was analyzed using the drift-diffusion model (DDM) [46][47][48], which allowed us to estimate participants' decision threshold-that is, how much information they require to make a decision-which directly governs their speed-accuracy trade-off preference (Figure 1b). We also measured how strongly participants weighted the social information they received (i.e., their partner's response) by applying a social DDM [26,27,31] (SDDM; Figure 1c).

We found that pair members with lower decision thresholds were more likely to act as leaders, and that these individuals set an upper bound on a pair's mean accuracy. That is, the presence of fast (and inaccurate) individuals is detrimental to overall group accuracy. Pair members with higher decision thresholds (who were therefore more accurate) did not shape overall group accuracy. We also observed that the pair members with the higher decision threshold weighted social information less than their faster partners did. Using simulations, we show that these adjustments in social information weighting are adaptive when facing an individual with a different speed-accuracy trade-off preference.

div.head: Task
div.p: We recruited 84 participants from Prolific to perform an online visual perception task ( Figure 1a) in a personal and a social condition. In the personal condition, participants observed a sequence of dot stimuli containing a total of 40 red and blue dots for 0.33 s and decided, within 10 s, which color was dominant. Participants received 100 points (= £0.02) for correct responses, with a 2-point penalty for each second taken; they received nothing for incorrect responses. They then were told the correct answer.

In the social condition, participants were randomly paired with another participant; they then performed the task together. The task was identical to the personal condition, except that whenever one pair member made a decision, the other member saw it in real time ("Social information" in Figure 1a). Pair members viewed the same stimuli and were rewarded only for the accuracy of their own decisions. See Methods for full experimental details.

div.head: (S)DDM and regression analyses
div.p: We modeled participants' decision processes in the personal condition using the DDM [46][47][48], which assumes that individuals accumulate stochastic evidence toward a decision boundary at a constant rate (i.e., the personal drift rate; Figure 1b). The personal drift rate can be interpreted as perceptual sensitivity [49]. When the evidence reaches one of two boundaries (i.e., red or blue), the individual chooses the corresponding option. Hereafter, we refer to the distance between the two boundaries as the threshold. The threshold indicates how much evidence an individual needs to make a decision and thus governs their speedaccuracy trade-off preference. Higher decision thresholds (i.e., weighting accuracy over

div.head: Own decision
div.p: Personal drift rate speed) are typically interpreted as more conservative decision-making [49].

We modeled participants' decision processes in the social condition using the SDDM ( Figure 1c) [26,27,31], which has an additional parameter, the social drift rate. This is an additional drift toward the option chosen by the individual's partner, and thus represents the degree of reliance on social information. See Supplementary Methods ("Parameter estimation", "Parameter recovery", and "Posterior predictive check"), Supplementary Figures S1 and S2, and Supplementary Table S1 for details of the analyses and results. ("Regression analyses") and Supplementary Table S2 for details of the analyses.

div.head: Individual differences in speed-accuracy trade-off preferences: Personal condition
div.p: We first investigated participants' accuracy and response time in the personal condition. That is, participants with higher thresholds and stronger personal drift rates made more accurate decisions. Individuals with higher thresholds had longer response times (b = 1.45 To further investigate the suitability of the DDM for this paradigm, we ran DDM simulations using the ranges of participants' individual estimates (see "DDM simulations to predict accuracy and response time" in Supplementary Methods for details).

div.head: Pair-level behavior
div.p: Equal overall accuracy in personal and social condition.
We next examined whether social coupling improved or worsened accuracy. Figure S3b for the relationship between response time and accuracy in the social condition).

To check whether social information affected participants' decisions, we compared the accuracy of the second-deciding member-the follower-when the first-deciding memberthe leader-was correct and they were wrong. Followers' accuracy was credibly higher when the leader was correct than when the leader was wrong (b = 2.11 [1.78, 2.45]; Figure 3b).
This result suggests that individuals, at least partly, followed social information.

div.head: Less conservative members led pairs.
div.p: To explore which individual-and pair-level characteristics determined the decision dynamics of pairs-that is, who produced/used social information and who contributed to pair-level In sum, pairs were led by the members whose decision-making was less conservative (i.e., who had lower decision thresholds), and this determined pairs' overall accuracy. However, decisions in the social condition were, overall, not worse than decisions in the personal condition (Figure 3a). In the next section, we turn to possible adaptations that may have prevented a deterioration of decisions in the social condition.

div.head: Pair-member adjustments
div.p: Pair members coordinated their thresholds.

Our analysis suggests that thresholds estimated from the personal condition play a key role in the decision-making processes in the social condition. However, it is also possible that individuals change the parameters of their cognitive architecture as a result of the social interactions.

To investigate this possibility, we first studied whether pair members coordinated their thresholds during the social condition. We found that pair members' thresholds were The shuffled pairs showed no significant within-pair correlations in the threshold (Supplementary Figure S4a). The other DDM parameters, personal drift rate and nondecision time, had no significant within-pair correlations in the personal or social conditions (Supplementary Figure S4c,d). Members with lower thresholds had higher social drift rates.
The higher an individual's social drift rate, the more they incorporated social information into their evidence accumulation process (see Figure 1c and Methods for details of the SDDM).

div.head: Simulations examining the impact of social drift rate on accuracy.
div.p: To examine how social drift rate impacts individual accuracy for lower-and higher threshold members, we ran simulations using participants' SDDM estimates from the social condition.

Each agent in a pair was assigned a participant's estimates of threshold, personal drift rate, and non-decision time from the social condition, and the 42 pairs from the experiment were simulated. To study the effect of the social drift rate, we varied each agent's social drift rate from −0.5 to 1.5 in increments of 0.1, covering the empirical range found in the social condition (Figure 5a). We performed 10,000 simulations (trials) for each pair and calculated the mean accuracy for each pair member. Lower-threshold member drift is 0) was relatively small (± 1.5%), implying that substantial accuracy improvements in the social condition are unlikely (see also Figure 3a). Finally, in the simulations, the accuracy of higher-threshold members suffered when they relied too heavily on social information.
Hence, we expected higher-threshold members to have lower social drift rates than lowerthreshold members, as was indeed found in the empirical data (Figure 5a).
Simulations incorporating the within-pair difference in thresholds.

Alongside the effect of social drift rate, there was another consequence of interaction in the social condition: Pair members' thresholds were positively correlated (Figure 4a). We therefore ran a second simulation to examine the impact of within-pair differences in thresholds on accuracy. We varied the threshold of the lower-threshold member (1, 2, 3, or 4), the within-pair difference in threshold (from 0 to 2 in increments of 0.1), and the social drift rate (from −0.5 to 1.5 in increments of 0.1). All these ranges roughly match the empirical distributions. As in the first simulation, we generated 42 pairs and 10,000 trials for each combination of the three parameters. We used individuals' estimates from the social condition for agents' personal drift rate and non-decision time.

We can draw three observations from the results of the simulations shown in Figure 5c. First, the color of subpanels gets brighter from bottom to top regardless of whether agents had higher or lower thresholds. This pattern indicates that agents became more accurate as their thresholds increased (see also Figure 2c). Second, for pair members with lower thresholds (left column), the optimal social drift rates (white dots and lines) lie between 0.5 and 1.0 regardless of their own threshold and the within-pair difference in threshold. This is consistent with Figure 5b and suggests that a positive social drift rate is beneficial to members with lower thresholds. Finally, for pair members with higher thresholds (right column), the optimal social drift rates decrease as a function of the within-pair threshold in a pair approaching zero (i.e., no reliance on social information) for large within-pair differences in thresholds. This pattern was independent of the threshold of the lower-threshold member.
These results match the empirical results shown in Figure 5a (right panel of scatter plots).

Although the main accuracy of a pair and the accuracy of the pair's leader depended only on the lower-threshold member (Figure 3e,g), accuracy in the social condition was not worse than in the personal condition (Figure 3a). The simulation results shown in Figure 5b,c suggest two mechanisms that prevented pairs from becoming less accurate: Lower-threshold members increased their thresholds in the social condition and became more accurate, and higher-threshold members incorporated less social information.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Although speed-accuracy trade-offs are fundamental to almost all decision-making contexts [1][2][3], previous research on human group decision-making has largely ignored the role of individual differences in speed-accuracy trade-off preferences. We therefore combined a realtime interactive study with modeling and simulating individual differences in decision conservativeness, perceptual sensitivity, and social information use. Our study produced three major findings.

First, pair members with lower thresholds in the personal condition made decisions earlier (i.e., became the leader) in the social condition (Figure 3c), thereby limiting pair-level accuracy (Figure 3g). This result is consistent with previous studies showing that earlier decisions affect later ones in sequential group decision-making in humans [26][27][28][29][30][31] and other animal groups [50,51]. Pair members' perceptual sensitivity, as indexed by personal drift rate, did not affect pair-level accuracy (Figure 3h). Individual differences in speed-accuracy trade-off preference can therefore be detrimental to sequential decision-making, since less accurate members may trigger chains of less accurate information that may be difficult for more accurate members to correct. Future work could test whether similar mechanisms operate in real-world contexts, such as collective attention [52], consumer choices in online markets [53], and risk communication in medical treatments [54]. Future work could also investigate whether the effects of initial biases can be amplified in sequential decisionmaking, because individuals with more extreme initial biases have been predicted to decide earlier [35]. Our results contrast with earlier work showing that more confident or knowledgeable members decide first in sequential group decisions, leading to better social decisions [26,28]. These differences may be the result of different group sizes-previous studies used substantially larger groups-or experimental stimuli. In our task, decision speed was mostly governed by threshold (and not personal drift rate), but social interactions may be more beneficial in tasks in which decision speed is also a function of personal drift rate.
Second, pair members reciprocally adjusted their thresholds to each other (Figure 4a,b).

These results are in line with previous research showing that humans adjust the parameters of their cognitive architecture mutually through social interaction [55,56] or after observing the behavior of others [57][58][59][60][61][62]. There is also evidence that other group-living animals adjust their decision speed in response to group members [63,64]. Although individual heterogeneity plays an important role in collective decision-making [65][66][67][68], one direction for future research will be to examine how individuals' malleability and reciprocity to social influences affect the dynamics of collective behavior (e.g., reducing individual statistical independence [69], boosting individual competence [70,71], and accelerating consensus-building in a group [72]).

Finally, pair members adjusted their social information use depending on whether they had the higher or lower threshold in their pair (Figure 5a). Although accuracy did not improve in the social condition (Figure 3b), simulation analyses suggest that pairs used social information adaptively (Figure 5b). This finding is consistent with previous studies showing that individuals can adjust their weighting of social information depending on its accuracy [43][44][45]. Future research could directly investigate the processes of learning the quality of social information and adaptive weight adjustments, for example by using a reinforcement learning framework. Here we estimated fixed weights on social information. In reality, however, individuals' social drift rate will most likely change over the course of the experiment, depending on their evolving assessment of the quality of their partners' responses compared to their own. Here the learning environment is likely a key moderator. In our design, participants received feedback after each trial, making it relatively easy for them to learn their accuracy as well as that of their partners. In situations without such feedback (e.g., [73][74][75]), adaptive social weighting may be more challenging, and negative effects of individual differences in speed-accuracy trade-off preference may be even more pronounced.

The DDM has been instrumental in revealing human cognitive processes in a wide variety of real-world contexts, including perception [76], purchasing [39], altruism [77,78], and police shootings [79,80]. Almost all work in real-world contexts has focused on individual decision-

making-yet humans rarely make decisions alone. Instead, humans often make decisions under social influence [29,81,82], which can amplify individual biases and result in group polarization [83] (e.g., information cascades [32,34], economic bubbles [84], superstar phenomena in product popularity [53], and collective rule-breaking [85,86]). There is ample opportunity to investigate the dynamics in real-world contexts through the lens of the DDM by, for instance, testing how individual differences in speed-accuracy trade-off preferences affect who decides first, how this information is transmitted through groups, and how individuals in turn adjust their cognitive architecture. To better understand and tackle collective human behavior, future studies would benefit from focusing on interactive situations, combined with cognitive modeling [38,87].

div.head: Participants
div.p: We recruited participants without color vision deficiency online using Prolific ( Prolific approval rating greater than 90% were allowed to participate.

The number of participants was determined based on previous studies on dyadic decisionmaking [36,37,55,88,89]. The duration of a session was set at around 30 min; the number of trials-76 per condition-was determined accordingly. See "Data exclusion" in Supplementary Methods for data exclusion criteria.

div.head: Experimental procedure
div.p: Overview.

Participants started with 76 trials in a personal condition, followed by another 76 in a social condition. In the personal condition, participants completed the task alone. In the social condition, they completed the task with another participant while simultaneously seeing each other's answers in real time. Participants then completed a post-session questionnaire (Supplementary Methods) and received a £4 base fee plus a bonus (range: £1.20-£2.80), resulting in an hourly wage of approximately £12.

div.head: Task.
div.p: We used a modified version of the task and stimuli in [90]. In the personal condition, participants observed a sequence of dot stimuli for up to 10 s (Figure 1a The small time cost was introduced to prevent participants from waiting until the last second for their partner's response in the social condition [26]. Before the personal condition, all participants passed comprehension quizzes and completed eight practice trials, which were excluded from the analyses.

In the social condition, participants were anonymously paired with another participant who had also finished the personal condition. In pairs, they performed the same task as in the personal condition and observed the same sequence of stimuli in a given trial. They also received social information-namely, their partner's choice-in real time ("Social information" in Figure 1a). Participants could not alter their decision once made. Both participants were shown their partner's choice in real time. Participants' rewards were solely based on their individual performance, and participants were told that they were not in competition.

div.head: Stimuli.
div.p: The 40 red and blue dots (radius: 6 pixels) were placed randomly in the center of a white circle (radius: 200 pixels) such that they did not overlap (Figure 1a). In half of the trials in each condition the correct option was red (M = +4); in the other half it was blue (M = -4). The number of red minus blue dots followed a truncated normal distribution with M = ±4 and SD = 16 lying within ±40, and was rounded to the nearest even number. These settings were chosen to elicit individual accuracy of approximately 75%. The trial order was pseudorandomized such that there were no more than five consecutive trials of the same correct answer. In the social condition, the correct answer was identical for both pair members, since they observed the same stimuli.

Red and blue circles were presented on the left and right sides of the screen, respectively, to remind participants which keys (left or right arrow) corresponded to the options. A participant's choice was indicated with a white square around their selected color; their partner's choice was indicated with a filled circle ("Social information" in Figure 1a).
Whenever a participant made a decision, the stimuli of colored dots disappeared for them (but not for their partner). The experiment was programmed using oTree [91].

div.head: Analyses Regression analyses.
div.p: Supplementary Table S2 shows the details of the regression models (probability distributions, variables, model formulas, random-effect structures). Here, we describe each model and its aim.

We first analyzed how the DDM parameters related to individual accuracy and mean response time. We ran a linear regression predicting individual accuracy from threshold and personal drift rate (Figure 2b), and an ex-Gaussian regression predicting individual mean response time from threshold and personal drift rate (Supplementary Figure S3a). To compare individual accuracy between the conditions (Figure 3a), we performed a logistic regression To analyze how within-pair differences in threshold and personal drift rate predicted who in a pair was more likely to be the leader in the social condition (Figure 3c,d), we performed a logistic regression predicting whether the member with the lower threshold was the leader or follower in the trial (follower = 0; leader = 1) from the within-pair differences in thresholds in the personal condition (Figure 3c). Similarly, we performed a logistic regression predicting whether the member with the higher drift rate was the leader or follower in the trial from the within-pair differences in personal drift rate in the personal condition (Figure 3d). The models for Figure 3c,d had only pair identity as a random-effect structure and included random intercepts and slopes. We then examined the impact of the thresholds and personal drift rates on leaders' accuracy (Figure 3e,f). We ran a logistic regression predicting the To investigate whether pair members reciprocally adjusted their thresholds to each other, we performed a linear regression predicting changes in threshold (from the personal to the social condition) from whether the participant had a higher or lower threshold in the personal condition (higher = 0; lower = 1; density plots in Figure 4b). To examine how much participants changed their thresholds, we performed a linear regression predicting changes in threshold from the within-pair difference in threshold, whether the participant had a higher or lower threshold in the personal condition (higher = 0; lower = 1), and their interaction effect (scatter plot in Figure 4b). To explore how within-pair differences in thresholds affected accuracy improvement, we performed a linear regression predicting changes in accuracy from within-pair differences in thresholds, whether the participants had a higher or lower threshold in the personal condition (lower = 0; higher = 1), and their interaction effect (Figure 4c).

Similarly, we performed a linear regression predicting changes in accuracy from changes in thresholds, whether the participants had a higher or lower threshold in the personal condition (lower = 0; higher = 1), and their interaction effect (Figure 4d).

To examine whether pair members adjusted their social information use depending on whether they had the higher or lower threshold in their pair, we performed a linear regression predicting social drift rates from whether the participant had a higher or lower threshold in the personal condition (higher = 0; lower = 1; density plots in Figure 5a). We also performed a linear regression predicting social drift rates from within-pair differences in thresholds and whether the participant had a higher or lower threshold in the personal condition (lower = 0; higher = 1), and their interaction effect (the scatter plot in Figure 5a). To compare participants' estimates of (S)DDM parameters between the conditions ( Figure S2e), we performed linear regressions, each predicting individual parameter estimates from the condition (personal = 0; social = 1). To examine color biases in the personal drift rates, we fitted the difference between the drift rates for blue and red (blue minus red) to the normal distribution (Supplementary Figure S2f). The models for Supplementary Figure S2e,f had participants as a random-effect structure and included random intercepts and slopes. We also performed a linear regression predicting relative social drift rates from whether the participants had a lower or higher threshold in the pair (higher = 0; lower = 1;
Supplementary Figure S2g).

Null hypothesis tests were performed in the parameter recovery ( Supplementary Figure S1) and the analyses for within-pair correlations in parameters (Figure 4a, & Supplementary Figure S4). All p-values were two-sided, and the significance level was set at 5%.
The DDM and SDDM.
The DDM for the personal condition (Figure 1b) had four parameters: decision threshold (θ), non-decision time (τ, in seconds), initial bias, and personal drift rates toward correct options:

δred or δblue if red or blue was the correct option, respectively. The decision threshold represents the distance between the two decision boundaries, with one boundary at zero (choosing red) and the other at θ (choosing blue). The non-decision time reflects the initial duration that passed without any evidence accumulation (e.g., motor response). To obtain reasonable estimates, the non-decision time was constrained between 0 and 1 s, following previous research (e.g., [92,93]). The initial bias represents where evidence accumulation started between the thresholds (e.g., prior expectation or preference for one option over the other). The initial bias was fixed at 0.5 s, exactly in the middle of the boundaries, because participants had no information about the correct answer before seeing the stimuli. Personal drift rates capture the absolute trend of the accumulation toward the correct options. Given these parameters, the evidence accumulation follows the stochastic process ! !" " ∼ Normal(δ, σ # ) with the scaling parameter σ fixed to 1. The decision time is modeled as the first time at which evidence hits either boundary.
The SDDM for the social condition (Figure 1c) had an additional parameter: social drift rate (δsocial). The social drift rate reflects an additional drift toward a partner's chosen option.
Thus, the drift rate (δ) after the presentation of social information at a trial is:

where a is the correct answer (blue = +1, red = −1), and s is the social information in the trial (blue = +1, red = −1). Note that δred is an absolute personal drift rate toward the lower boundary. Therefore, δred is multiplied by a minus sign in Equation 1. The average of δblue and δred was used as an index of the participant's personal drift rate.

figure.head: Figure 1 .
figure.figDesc: Task and drift-diffusion models (DDMs). (a) Trial flow. (b) Illustration of the DDM. (c) Illustration of the social DDM (SDDM) with two agents. Non-decision time is omitted from panels (b) and (c) for simplicity.

The experimental data were analyzed using Bayesian hierarchical generalized linear (mixed) models. Below we report the median and 95% highest-density interval (HDI) of posterior statistics of interest (ρ = Spearman correlation coefficient; r = Pearson correlation coefficient; b = standardized regression coefficient; M = mean). See Supplementary Methods

figure.head: Figure 2a shows a
figure.figDesc: credible positive correlation between an individual's mean response time and their accuracy in the personal condition (ρ = .57 [.39, .76]). This result shows that participants who took more time to decide were also more accurate. There were substantial individual differences in both speed and accuracy of decisions. Participants' mean response time was 2.27 s; mean accuracy was 67.4%. As expected, individual accuracy increased as a function of both threshold and personal drift rate (Figure 2b; threshold: b = 0.06 [0.06, 0.07]; personal drift rate: b = 0.07 [0.06, 0.07]).

33, 1.56]), whereas the effect of the personal drift rate on response times was not credible (b = −0.06 [−0.12, 0.01]; Supplementary Figure S3a). There was no credible correlation between threshold and personal drift rate (Figure 2b; r = −.19 [−.41, .03]).

Figure 2cand d shows that these DDM predictions were consistent with the empirical results (Figure 2b, Supplementary Figure S3a): Accuracy increased as a function of both threshold and personal drift rate, whereas response time increased predominantly as a function of threshold.See alsoSupplementary Figure S3c,dfor accuracy and mean response time over trials.

figure.head: Figure 2 .
figure.figDesc: Individual differences in the personal condition. (a) Mean individual response time (RT) and accuracy in the personal condition. Each dot represents one participant. The blue line indicates the locally estimated scatterplot smoothing (LOESS); the shaded area indicates the 95% confidence interval. (b) Participants' personal drift rates and thresholds in the personal condition. Each dot represents one participant. (c) Predicted individual accuracy. Colors represent predicted individual accuracy from 1,000 simulations for each combination of threshold and personal drift rate. See panel b for legend. (d) Predicted mean individual response times. Colors represent the predicted mean individual response time from 1,000 simulations.

Figure 3a shows no credible difference in individual accuracy between the personal and social conditions (b = 0.01 [−0.10, 0.11]): On average, social coupling was neither beneficial nor detrimental to individual accuracy (see Supplementary

figure.head: Figure 3 .
figure.figDesc: Pair-level accuracy and drift-diffusion model (DDM) parameters. (a) Individual accuracy in the personal and social conditions. (b) Accuracy of second decisions in a pair. Each dot indicates a participant but can be based on a different number of underlying trials. (c, d) Probability of being the leader and within-pair difference in (c) threshold and (d) personal drift rate. (e, f) Leaders' accuracy as a function of higher and lower (e) thresholds and (f) personal drift rates in a pair. (g, h) Pairs' mean accuracy as a function of higher and lower (g) thresholds and (h) personal drift rates in a pair. In panels c-h, fitted lines indicate the mean conditional effects (solid line = credible effect; dashed line = non-credible effect); shaded areas indicate the 95% uncertainty intervals of the mean.

difference in personal drift rate accuracy-we first examined the effects of within-pair differences in threshold and personal drift rate on the probability of being the leader in a pair. The within-pair differences in the parameters were based on the personal condition so as to have independent estimates of participants' personal drift rates and thresholds.The probability of the pair member with the lower threshold (as estimated from the personalcondition) being the leader increased as a function of the within-pair difference in threshold (b = 0.76 [0.31, 1.24]; Figure 3c). Overall, pairs therefore tended to be led by the member who had collected less perceptual evidence (Figure 1b) and thus may have been less accurate (Figure 2b,c). This effect increased with an increasing difference in threshold between pair members. Within-pair differences in personal drift rate had no credible effect on the probability of being the leader (b = 0.08 [−0.27, 0.50]; Figure 3d). These results match the finding from the personal condition that response times (and by extension leadership) are mostly governed by thresholds and not personal drift rates (Figure 2d). Based on these results, we examined what determined the accuracy of the leaders. Given that leaders tended to have the lower threshold in their pair, we expected that the accuracy of the first response in a pair would predominantly be a function of the threshold of the pair member with the lower, not the higher, threshold. As Figure 3e shows, the threshold of the member with the lower threshold in a pair had a positive effect on the leader's individual accuracy (b = 0.19 [0.03, 0.33]). In other words, the lower the threshold of the lower-threshold pair members, the worse the first decisions were. The threshold of the higher-threshold member had no credible effect on the accuracy of first decisions (b = −0.02 [−0.18, 0.16]). Personal drift rates had no effect on the accuracy of first decisions for either member (lower personal drift rate: b = −0.09 [−0.25, 0.07]; higher personal drift rate: b = 0.02 [−0.14, 0.18]; Figure 3f). We observed a similar pattern for the mean accuracy of the pairs: Pairs' mean accuracy increased as a function of the threshold of the lower-threshold member (b = 0.12 [0.01, 0.23]; Figure 3g). There was no effect of the threshold of the higher-threshold member (b = 0.01 [−0.12, 0.13]; Figure 3g). Similar to leaders' accuracy, the personal drift rates did not affect pairs' accuracy (lower personal drift rate: b = −0.07 [−0.18, 0.04]; higher personal drift rate: b = −0.00 [−0.12, 0.11]; Figure 3h).

positively correlated in the social condition (mean r = .56, p < .001;Figure 4a, left panel; see "Within-pair correlation in the DDM parameters" in Supplementary Methods for details of the analyses). To rule out the possibility that this result was due to members of pairs having similar thresholds before coming together (e.g., as a result of non-random assignment of individuals to pairs), we checked this relationship in the personal condition. We found that pair members' thresholds did not correlate in the personal condition (mean r = .08, p = .586;Figure 4a, right panel). As another control, we randomly shuffled pair members in the social condition, forming new virtual pairs, and calculated within-pair correlations in the threshold.

figure.head: Figure 4 .
figure.figDesc: Changes in threshold and accuracy. (a) Within-pair correlation in thresholds. The axes show pair members' thresholds. The labels Member 1 and 2 are randomly assigned within each pair. For details of the analysis, see "Within-pair correlation in the DDM parameters" in Supplementary Methods. (b) Reciprocal adjustment in threshold within pairs. (c) Accuracy improvement as a function of within-pair difference in the threshold in the personal condition. (d) Accuracy improvement as a function of change in threshold. In panels (b-d), fitted lines indicate the mean conditional effects (solid line = credible effect; dashed line = non-credible effect); shaded areas indicate the 95% uncertainty intervals of the mean. We next examined which pair member(s) adjusted their threshold and in which direction. The pair member with the lower threshold increased their threshold in the social condition, whereas the pair member with the higher threshold decreased theirs (lower-threshold member: M = 0.25 [0.08, 0.42]; higher-threshold member: M = −0.36 [−0.54, −0.18]; see density plots in Figure 4b). These changes in threshold were credibly different between the pair members (b = 0.61 [0.36, 0.87]). The changes in threshold also credibly changed as a function of the distance in thresholds between pair members (lower-threshold member: b = 0.23 [0.08, 0.39]; higher-threshold member: b = −0.35 [−0.50, −0.19]; see scatter plots in

figure.head: Figure 4b ).
figure.label: 4b
figure.figDesc: The interaction effect was credible (b = 0.58 [0.37, 0.80]). These results suggest that both pair members adjusted their thresholds reciprocally through interaction. The changes in thresholds were also reflected in responses to a post-session questionnaire about the social condition (see "Post-session questionnaire" in Supplementary Methods for difference in threshold in the personal condition Within-pair difference in threshold in the personal condition details). Lower-threshold members who reported that they had deliberately delayed their responses in the social condition had indeed reduced their threshold more in the social condition (ρ = .48 [.19, .77]; Supplementary Figure S5a). A similar, albeit not credible, association was found for the higher-threshold members (ρ = .24 [−.04, .53]). We also explored whether differences or changes in thresholds affected accuracy improvement from the personal to social condition. No credible relationships were observed between the within-pair differences in threshold and the accuracy improvement for either member (lower-threshold member: b = −0.02 [−0.04, 0.01]; higher-threshold member: b = −0.00 [−0.03, 0.03]; Figure 4c). Increasing the threshold of higher-threshold members from the personal to the social condition increased their accuracy (b = 0.03 [0.00, 0.06]; Figure 4d). This relationship was not credible for the lower-threshold members (b = 0.03 [−0.01, 0.06]). The interaction effect was not credible (b = −0.00 [−0.04, 0.04]).

figure.head: Figure 5a shows the
figure.figDesc: social drift rates of participants, separately for pair members with lower and higher thresholds. Both lower-and higher-threshold pair members had credibly positive social drift rates (lower threshold: M = 0.58 [0.50, 0.66]; higher threshold: M = 0.40 [0.32, 0.48]). Almost all participants followed social information, confirming the result shown inFigure 3b (see Supplementary Figure S2g for social drift rates relative to personal drift rates). Lower-threshold members had credibly higher social drift rates than higher-threshold members (b = 0.18 [0.07, 0.29]; see density plot in Figure 5a). In addition, for higherthreshold members only, social drift rates decreased credibly as a function of within-pair difference in thresholds (lower threshold: b = 0.05 [−0.02, 0.12]; higher threshold: b = −0.09 [−0.16, −0.02]; see scatter plot in Figure 5a). The interaction effect was credible (b = −0.14 [−0.25, −0.04]). In sum, members with higher thresholds in the personal condition (i.e,. those who required more information to make decisions, and generally made better decisions) gave less weight to social information than did their less conservative counterparts. Participants who reported in the post-session questionnaire that they had relied more on social information also had higher social drift rate estimates (lower-threshold members: ρ = .33 [.01, .64]; higher-threshold members: ρ = .11 [−.20, .40]; SupplementaryFigure S5b).

figure.head: Figure 5 .
figure.figDesc: Social drift rate and simulation results. (a) Social drift rates and within-pair difference in thresholds. Fitted lines indicate the mean conditional effects (solid line = credible effect; dashed line = non-credible effect); shaded areas indicate the 95% uncertainty intervals of the mean. (b) Simulated individual accuracy as a function of social drift rate. Error bars indicate the standard errors of the means. (c) Simulated individual accuracy as a function of within-pair difference in threshold, social drift rate, and the lower threshold in a pair. White dots and dashed spline curves indicate the optimal social drift rates (y-axis).

figure.head: Figure 5b shows the
figure.figDesc: simulated accuracy as a function of social drift rates for the higher-and lower-threshold pair members. In the simulations both pair members profited from a positive social drift rate. However, the difference between the maximum possible accuracy (at the optimal level of social drift) and an individual's accuracy without any social drift (i.e., social Lower threshold member Higher threshold

). Each stimulus lasted for 0.33 s and contained a mix of 40 red and blue dots. While the stimuli were presented (i.e., within the 10 s), participants had to identify the dominant color. If the participant did not answer within 10 s, the stimuli disappeared and an extra 3 s countdown timer appeared to prompt a response in order to minimize the number of missed trials.Participants chose their color by pressing the left-or right-arrow key. The key-color combination was counterbalanced across participants. At the end of each trial, participants received feedback on their answer. They earned points (= £0.02) for a correct response, minus 2 points per second they took to answer; they earned nothing for a wrong response.

predicting the choices (incorrect = 0; correct = 1) from the condition (personal = 0; social = 1). To examine the impact of social information on followers' accuracy (Figure 3b), we conducted a logistic regression predicting the followers' responses (incorrect = 0; correct = 1) from the leaders' responses (incorrect = 0; correct = 1). The models for Figure 3a,b had individual and pair identity as random-effect structures to account for individual and pairlevel variance, and the predictor included random slopes.

leaders' choices (incorrect = 0; correct = 1) from their pair members' estimates of threshold and personal drift rate in the personal condition. Similarly, we performed a logistic regression predicting pairs' accuracy from pair members' estimates of the DDM parameters(Figure 3g,h). The models forFigure 3e-h included individual and pair identity as random-effect structures as well as random intercepts and slopes.

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: We thank Mariko Ito, Hisashi Ohtsuki, and Tatsuya Kameda for their feedback on the conceptualization of this project and Deborah Ain for editing the manuscript.

div.head: Ethics
div.p: All participants gave informed consent before the experiment. All procedures of this study were approved by the Institutional Review Board of the Max Planck Institute for Human Development (A 2023-19) and were conducted in accordance with relevant guidelines and regulations.

div.head: Data availability
div.p: The experimental materials, data, and analysis codes that support the findings of this study are available on OSF (https://osf.io/kw23d/?view_only=a79b7b1d746c40388c4c0351b3f1427f).

div.head: Declaration of AI use
div.p: We did not use AI-assisted technologies in writing this article.

div.head: Competing interests
div.p: The authors declare no competing interests.
